page.title: 06FARMING, SHEEP BREEDS
page.content: Although the annual wool clip provides one source of farm income, this is only secondary to the income derived from the sale of fat lambs, aided by the current EEC Sheepmeat Regime. Consequently the selecton of stock breeds and the management of the flocks is geared to meat rather than wool production. The native breed is the WELSH MOUNTAIN SHEEP, but in this area it has been improved by crossing with CHEVIOT rams to produce the BRECKNOCK HILL CHEVIOT- a recognised separate breed. Further crossing with lowland breeds, notably the SUFFOLK, has greatly improved the size and weight of lambs.Each farm has its resident flock of breeding ewes to which is added each years crop of ewe lambs. Ram lambs are sold for slaught -er at about 6 months old. No wethers are kept.
